This American Association of Medicine's article shows how reading for pleasure reduces physician burnout by improving empathy and combating depersonalization. â€œThere is an effect of literature on physicians that nothing else can have. Literature creates attention you really canâ€™t create through anything else. ... It creates a better connection to patients.â€ To determine how reading impacts physician burnout, Dr. Marchalik sent surveys to 2,500 doctors. Questions addressed burnout, demographics and reading patterns. Through the process of reading, physicians often exhibit empathy. Researchers then looked at theory-of-mind testing, which is often used when screening for autism. â€œWhat they show is those who read literary fiction actually performed better in theory of mind, which is actually a surrogate for measuring empathy,â€ said Dr. Marchalik. â€œItâ€™s doing something special. ... â€œIt is moving the needle on what is probably the most difficult part of burnout to move the needle on, which is depersonalization,â€ he added. One survey of 513 physicians examined the impact of non-medical reading habits on burnout. The chances of emotional exhaustion or depersonalization fell as physicians became more consistent readers. When compared to nonreaders, the relative risk of burnout for consistent readersâ€”those who read at least one book per monthâ€”fell by 19 percent across the emotional exhaustion and 44 percent across the depersonalization domain. In an unpublished study by Dr. Marchalik, more than 200 urology trainees were surveyed about work characteristics, as well as relaxation techniques. These included watching movies, meditation, yoga, reading and other ways of relaxing. Meditation, exercise and yoga were not protective against burnoutâ€” but reading was. Controlling for the biggest predictors of burnout, which were resident level, work hours and gender, reading made an impact: the odds of burnout decreased by 59 percent for residents who read for relaxation. A similar effect was seen in Dr. Marchalikâ€™s national survey of palliative care providers, in which the odds of burnout dropped by 39 percent for readers, even when controlling for age, clinical discipline and the presence of fatigue. Chances of being a reader later in life are significantly higher when literature curriculum is offered in medical school. This raises the chances of being protected from physician burnout too. â€œPlanting those seeds early makes a huge difference,â€ said Dr. Marchalik, who leads Georgetown Universityâ€™s Literature and Medicine Track. Medical students complete four years of the literature program, reading one book a month and conclude the program with a capstone writing project. https://lnkd.in/eqX4-5AM #reading #burnoutprevention #bibliotherapy #storiesforwellbeing

As an empath and extrovert, I always enjoyed starting up conversations with people. I could meet a stranger on a walk in the park and spend hours as we somehow transitioned into a conversation about their deepest, darkest secrets. I can tell that physicians are sometimes confused about my level of knowledge about spinal leaks. And so I will tell you my secret: I talk to people. I was a former PhD candidate working on my dissertation when my health worsened. With a background in teaching at the university level, conducting qualitative research and presenting on this nationally, and putting together instructional materials for school systems, I had the skills to review medical research articles and started reaching out to the physicians who had written the papers. I am also a former spinal leak patient of many of the big names publishing and am well aware of their shortcomings, having been on the receiving end. I networked with many patients as a de facto patient advocate as I grew my TikTok account and reported back on what I was learning from physicians and the research. I found that many of the other patients did not know how to find and analyze research studies, and so I broke this down for them. Building a database of over 5,000 physicians with an assistant, I started reaching out to interventional radiologists and anesthesiologists to gain a better understanding of how they would approach a similar problem. These physicians would sometimes be very open to an in-depth conversation, from telling me everything they knew about spinal leaks and what they had learned in their residencies and fellowships to explaining to me how to read imaging. I quickly recognized that nearly everyone held a small piece of the puzzle to solving spinal leaks but everyone was left in confusion at what the larger picture looked like. With some retired physicians, I offered to pay them to record courses to address the knowledge transfer gap. Time and time again, I saw a theme of them being very open with me as a civilian and even telling me extremely personal things about themselves, but the moment it came to connecting to and sharing with other doctors, they would shut down. At times, as I learned the terminology, they would assume that I was also a doctor even though I was very clear I was a patient. I always thought that the rude ones treated me rudely because I wasn't one of the initiated. One day, a doctor snapped at me after I had written to him and kept demanding to know who I was. I ignored him. A few days later, I got an email from him again. He apologized and was much nicer, saying he had thought I was another physician initially. We then ended up having a deeper conversation. That exchange made me think: do I have an advantage here? I have spent nearly three years with constant feedback and discussions on research with practicing and retired physicians on spinal leaks. Why were they open to teaching me and not younger physicians?
